121253: Stromgald Crusader.author: DarthParallax
121253: Stromgald Crusader.text_parsed:
Ride for Wrath! Ride for Ruin! And the Red Dawn!
Ride Now! Ride!
Death! Death! DEATH! Death!!!
D E A H T H !!!!!

16 Knights
1xWhite Knight
1xBlack Knight
1xStromgald Crusader
1xWhite Shield Crusader
1xSilver Knight
4xBlood Knight
1xKnight Exemplar
1xKnight of Glory
1xKnight of Infamy
1xPhyrexian Crusader
1xMirran Crusader

Here's where it gets interesting:

5 Clerics (21 creatures)
1x Kaalia of the Vast
4x Stoneforge Mystic

3 Big Dumb Monsters (24 creatures)
1x Akroma, Angel of Wrath
1x Griselbrand
1x Bogardan Hellkite

4 artifacts
1x Akroma's Memorial (of course I was going here)
1x Sword of Vengeance
1x Sword of War and Peace
1x Sword of Light and Shadow

8 Spells
4x Wrath of God
4x Planar Cleansing

While I am aware that nothing in this deck will save your creatures from your Wraths except for Knight Exemplar, I opted to use 1 instead of 4 of it deliberately- this deck has some really awe-inspiring potential, without being 'too much' for most playgroups to handle. It DOES however, pretty much *f* *u* nearly any and all SPOT removal cards in the game! ^_^

Kaalia was just an afterthought once I realized that the Knight Tribe happened to be very well-suited to her- nothing like an army of Knights being led by a Champion Angel, Demon, or Dragon! And the conflicts of Kaalia being somehow angelic and demonic are just awesome when you think of Knights of the 'wrong' color being teamed with Akroma or Griselbrand! :D

Figure the mana out yourself, but I surmise that Clifftop Retreatx4 Dragonskull Summitx4 and Isolated Chapelx4 would be good places to start :)

3/5

121261: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper.author: DoctorKenneth
121261: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper.text_parsed:
Well, many people have tried to answer Mode's question as to the flavourful difference between a Graveborn and a Zombie. I think we should look to Balduvian Dead, as its the only of the card that mentions the Graveborn. And once we look there, the answer is obvious:

Graveborn can grow some manly beards.

Despite dead flesh and years of decay, Graveborn corpses can both grow and maintain full beards in perfect condition. Made from the manliest of bodies, Graveborn innately have a Red nature- no doubt red mana is flowing through their hair follicles to add to their rugged allure. This excess of testosterone makes the Graveborn more reckless (but stronger) than the traditional zombie, accounting for its 3/1 frame. They are the Isaiah Mustafa of the undead, as it were.

So to answer your question, I have no idea.

121261: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper.author: WannabeJedi1337
121261: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper.text_parsed:
To answer the question, I scoured the internet, and i found this. (via the D&D wiki, which D&D is owned by WOTC)

Graveborn have escaped death. Once a race dies its corpse may become a graveborn. Some speculate that this is because the soul has not finished its life. Others say that it is a random occurrence. Graveborn have an unnerving presence about them that is as much a result of their cold flesh as their detached cunning and determination. They have a supernatural way with words and often get what they want, but, even so, they fear for their lives since once they only just escaped death.
Haunted continually by the whispers of those who died and were buried in their vicinity, some graveborn seek to escape the voices by venturing into the wilds as barbarians. Others try to drown them out with arcane music or the more preferable, though demanding, voice of a warlock patron. Since they harbor no memories of their former lives and find it difficult to retain even recent memories graveborn are often distant and unapproachable, even to those who have known them for decades. These whispers are totally insane and provide no valuable advice. They are heard only by the graveborn and are a byproduct of her having escaped death.

In other words, i have no idea what they are.

121261: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper.author: The_Murderauder
121261: Sek'Kuar, Deathkeeper.text_parsed:
I run him as the general of an EDH deck that I like to call ButtSeks.

I was tired of all the W/G and W/B/G token decks around, and wanted something different. Turns out he's really consistent and a blast to play. Lots of sac effects and recursion, as well at ETB effects and LTB effects make for a fun, intricate deck.

Things like Nether Traitor and Reassembling Skeleton (along with a sac outlet) let me bounce things in and out of play. Coupled with semi-repeatable recursion like Bloodghast, persist/undying creatures, Eternal Witness, Deadwood Treefolk, and things like Gleancrawler or Shirei, Shizo's Caretaker, Cauldron of Souls, or Mikaeus, the Unhallowed mean there's always stuff going on and things are always coming back from the dead.

To make my things dead, I use the usual sac outlets like Ashnod's/Phyrexian Altar, Altar of Dementia, Attrition, Mind Slash, Viscera Seer, Thoughtpicker Witch, Spawning Pit, whatever you want.

Golgari Germination, Pawn of Ulamog, and Gutter Grime have basically the same effect as Seks, but they make different types of tokens. Genesis Chamber triggers on ETB rather than LTB, but there's enough of both going on to make it basically the same thing.

To compliment the normal ramp/fixing you need in EDH decks, I stuck in stuff like Diligent Farmhand, Yavimaya Granger, Sakura-Tribe Elder, Dawntreader Elk, Viridian Emissary, and Yavimaya Elder to ramp while I sac and vice-versa.

Fecundity, Skullclamp, Soul of the Harvest, Harvester of Souls, and Dragon Appeasement are more than enough to keep my hand full. Also stuff like Grave Pact, Blood Artist, and Black Market make it so that stuff happens when my stuff dies.

Needless to say, Parallel Lives and Doubling Season are pretty snazzy here.

There are a number of ways to go infinite, but you shouldn't even really need (or want) to. There's plenty going on already, and it's quite deadly on its own.

121262: Tamanoa.author: Kurhan
121262: Tamanoa.text_parsed:
Way o no know your magic rules (except you Injuryman, you are correct).

Damage is not loss of life.
Loss of life is not damage.

Damage causes loss of life in most cases.
Loss of life does not cause damage in most cases.

Damage is preventable.
Loss of life is not.

Prevention is the opposite of damage.
Life gain is the opposite of loss of life.

Spells and abilities generally magnify damage, not loss of life. Ex: Furnace of Rath

Sanguine bond does not combo for infinite anything off this creature.
Sanguine bond requires you gain life to cause an opponent to lose an equal amount of life. It will double the amount of life lost by your opponent, assuming the damage all converted to loss of life.

This rules lesson was brought to you today by the number "666".

121262: Tamanoa.author: AssKickingBoots
121262: Tamanoa.text_parsed:
This card is awesome! I made a really rather effective deck built around this and Searing Meditation.

You need Painlands (Battlefield Forge, etc.) and/or the Mirrodin Talismans (Talisman of Unity, etc.), and an excuse to tap mana every turn (I use Isochron Scepter). With Tamanoa out, each instance of tapping a painland technically gains you life, allowing you to use Searing Meditation for each instance, you can tap yourself out to deal 2 damage per 2 mana while gaining an equal amount of life.

Multiple copies of Tamanoa stack, gaining you life each time you tap a painland and double on regular damage. I've easily reached into the hundreds of life in multiplayer games using this. If any of you are thinking that this combo sounds too Johnny-ish, you don't need all parts out for it to effectively work.

Having read the comments (particularly BinarySpike), I have to add Manabarbs to my deck. Manabarbs would count as a different source of damage than the painlands, making just one copy of Tamanoa still work for me while opponents lands hurt them and heal me (since Manabarbs is still my source). Yeah, I'm full well expecting to see Manabarbs get Counterbored the second time I ever try to play it.

121262: Tamanoa.author: Grakling
121262: Tamanoa.text_parsed:
@Megadog
If you notice, "tamanoa" is not capitalized in the flavor text. This means it's referring to "The tamanoa" as a group/species. It would be akin to the flavor text reading "When Freyalise spoke the World Spell, the elves rose to bring a new morning to Terisiare" Tamanoa is not an individual's name or title in this case, it is a race/species/culture.
While it might be nice for this to be legendary, simply for EDH purposes, the flavor indicates that it is merely one of many like it. I would be interested to see more creatures of this species, though. Perhaps a named one that actually is Legendary, and has a more powerful and/or similar ability. Even more interesting might be a Planeswalker from among them whose loyalty abilities revolve around you gaining life or adding extra abilities to spells you cast.

121263: Martyr of Sands.author: SGLinkmaster
121263: Martyr of Sands.text_parsed:
This is no doubt one of the best white one drops in the game for so many reasons.

1) Serra Ascendant can come out at full power on turn 2
2) The Chalice of Life can be activated very early game
3) Test of Endurance and Felidar Sovereign
4) Rune-Tail, Kitsune Ascendant can activate very early game, giving you a very solid advantage.

A must have in any mono white life gain decks.

121263: Martyr of Sands.author: DaMaster012
121263: Martyr of Sands.text_parsed:
By far, the absolute most evil use I've seen for this card was fabricated by my younger brother. He ran FOUR of them in an Orzhov deck that was built almost exclusively with multicolor and hybrid cards; multiple copies of sh!t like Edge of the Divinity, Divinity of Pride, Stillmoon Cavalier, Souls of the Faultless, Unmake, Voracious Hatchling, Mortify, Deathbringer Liege, Ghost Council of Orzhova for a sac engine, Debtors' Knell to get the sacrifices back, Angelic Chorus to be mean, Sanguine Bond to be even more mean, and Roiling Horror to be downright evil. (And a few Elixir of Immortality and Wrath of God for the Hell of it)

So with all of these extremely powerful white and black cards and the ability to gain on average 12 life per hand thanks to Martyr of Sands here, how did he utilize all that life to dig into his extraordinarily synergistic deck?

Yawmoth's Bargain.

I f*cking hated that deck.

(WotC Employee 3): Yeah! And then we'll make a creature WITH Demonic Tutor on it, and make it a flying demon!

(1): Yeah, Jim. Go away. No one wants you here. Ok, so now, lets give it... Trample!... And make it... a Wurm! Yeah!

And that's how Rune-Scarred Demon was created.

121264: Panglacial Wurm.author: The_Murderauder
121264: Panglacial Wurm.text_parsed:
Love love LOVE this dude. Mechanically wonderful, flavorfully hilarious, balanced and fun. A mite confusing to new players, but they get it when you explain it. The word "cast" really helps.

I run this guy in a mono-green ramp deck that works really well. The key is library searching that is free to activate. Usually I crack a fetchland or a Sakura-Tribe Elder mid-combat and kill some unsuspecting attacker, then he's ready to go kick some butt next turn.

Like I said, I absolutely love the mechanic, I think it's creative and inventive, works just as intended, and is neither over- nor under-powered. That said, I am so glad that it is confined to this one card. If this were a "regular" mechanic, and appeared on several cards (and god forbid those cards were actually good), Magic would become a boring, repetitive game, with much frustration and exasperation all around.
121264: Panglacial Wurm.text_posted:

121266: Ohran Viper.author: EternalLurker
121266: Ohran Viper.text_parsed: Though this card is indeed extraordinarily powerful, I should mention something that no one seems to be recognizing. This creature-destruction ability is far weaker than Deathtouch, since it can't distribute its combat damage among multiple blockers. "Effectively deathtouch" is simply not accurate. At 1/3, that won't be a noticeable difference, but since this is a mono-Green card, pumping it up will not result in multiple creatures dying to it, and that's important.

121266: Ohran Viper.author: JaxsonBateman
121266: Ohran Viper.text_parsed:
I can't believe I've never put together a decklist that used this fantastic little guy. One of the things I loved when I first started in Zendikar was Giant Scorpion making things tough for the opponent - do I let him niggle through for 1, or do I trade with him, giving up something of much more significant power?

Ohran Viper does this and then some. Do I trade with him, or do I let him niggle through *and* draw a card? That's your proverbial rock and a hard place right there.

Personally, I've just thrown it in a Mimic Vat deck - the 'deathtouch' style ability makes it pseudo-spot removal, and the card draw makes it something I don't mind paying 3 for each turn.

121266: Ohran Viper.author: raptorman333
121266: Ohran Viper.text_parsed:
@JaxsonBateman: It's just raw card advantage. You either kill a card on the other side or you gain a card on your side. Very blue in an available green flavor; oh, snakes.

Equip with infiltration lens and make it a lot easier to guarantee card draw and the probability that this little guy is going to stay around.

Want to make a snake deck? Include Lorescale Coatl. You draw cards, coatl gets bigger. They block the coatl with the lense, he gets bigger. They let the viper through, coatl gets bigger. They block the viper with the lense coatl gets even bigger and they lose a card. Throw rancor and the lense on the coatl and the coatl is likely to get through... and get bigger. Put a snake umbra on any of them and, you guessed it, the coatl gets bigger.

Screw it you can just build a blue...ehem, i mean control deck
the blue
this
(Seshiro the Anointed)
Plow Under
Stunted Growth
Shisato, Whispering Hunter
Sosuke's Summons
conjurer's closet
snake umbra
Keen Sense
the beef
masticore
rancor
serpent skin
molting skin
vigor
asceticism
whispersilk cloak or lightning greaves or swiftfoot boots or loxodon warhammer
throw in some land grab cards like sakura-tribe elder and yavimaya elder and you've got a deck

all in all 5/5 for this gem

121268: Adarkar Windform.author: Eluem
121268: Adarkar Windform.text_parsed:
Idk, I think this is a pretty cool card. Only thing that sucks is that it's ability is 2 mana instead of 1... but it could be useful in the right deck.

-Removing flying from other creatures so it can attack.

-Removing flying from creatures so you can block them with bigger blue creatures.

-It's an Illusion so it fits in with one of Blue's best creature types that's out now since the release of Lord of the Unreal

You could also throw it in a red/blue deck I guess.... allows you to Earthquake them. Probably only as a sideboard thing though...

But if all your lands are snow lands, then you can activate the ability with either color.

idk.. unless i'm missing something this is a decent utility creature.

3/5

121272: Balduvian Fallen.author: allmighty_abacus
121272: Balduvian Fallen.text_parsed:
@metalevolence... and anyone else who thinks that every card that isn't terrible should have at least 4 stars.

It's rated low because it's not on par with other higher ranked cards. Why is this such a difficult concept for people to grasp? The planeswalkers are 4 to 5 star cards because their ultimates can decide games, and their other two abilities are pretty swell. vines of vastwood is 4.5 stars, because not losing a fatty to terminate is always awesome. Psychatog is 4.5 stars because it was the win condition for virtually all the decks in Odyssey constructed. Cruel ultimatum is 4 stars because it creates a 10 point life gap and potentially a seven-card advantage and if you don't lose right then, its almost impossible to recover from it.

What does this card do again? Par for the course costing? Cu.mulative upkeep-powered firebreathing? A relevant creature type? Not at all a 4 or 5 star card, and even a stretch to call it 3.5 worthy. But 3 stars is not a "bad" rating. You won't expect anyone to be winning games with it, much less defining tourney play, but it has no serious flaws.

121272: Balduvian Fallen.author: Palochka
121272: Balduvian Fallen.text_parsed:
Braid of Fire's Card of the Day #13

My first expansion of Magic was Coldsnap, and regardless of the community consensus, it remains my favorite to this day. Many of my first games of Magic included this card, and even for myself and my younger brother, cumulative upkeep was very "grokable", even when compared to what is considered a basic keyword like First Strike. I enjoy the design space of the mechanic and now, having experienced a great wealth of the Ice Age and Alliances expansions I have to marvel on the design of cards like this, where cumulative upkeep is treated as a double-edged sword, leading to more interesting game states and only one moment where the decision needs to be made.

Though I fully understand R&D's shift away from "negative" mechanics such as this, I think Balduvian Fallen shows that it can be interesting and powerful, even in the hands of newer players. This was a welcome top-deck for a player with a month of experience under his belt, and when four mana was tapped on the opposite side of the table from me I had to pay close attention, even with my Auroch army.

This is a respectable black body (almost uncharacteristically so) that hints at black and red's connection though does not require it. In a two-color deck, the cumulative upkeep cost is essentially no different than . I really enjoyed how in the Ice Age block, friendly colors were made friendlier. It speaks back to the core of the game before Ravnica did away with the concept of "enemy colors" in many players' minds, in my opinion to the detriment of the game.

Good draft pick, solid beater, and most importantly, one of the most zombie looking zombies out there. It looks like it belongs in the Ice Age block, appears massive, and though there's a flavor disconnect about how paying for more and more mana makes him stronger only in the front, it's fun. This is a fun Magic card.

First of all; Braid of Fire
Second of all, this is quite good. The mana you are paying is Firebreathing in either color with a 3/5 body attached *at cost.*


Also, I think people are very spoiled with color-heavy mana costs. Something this color-light/splashable is very much on or above the curve. Yeah, Phyrexian Obliterator is ridiculous in black, and for one less CMC! But.. you can only play him in black or with rituals/mana fixers, can't use urza lands, can't use lands like wasteland to get him out, etc..

Colored mana is part of the powercreep, in addition to the bit of powercreep we already see.

121495: Lightning Storm.author: DacenOctavio
121495: Lightning Storm.text_parsed:
I thought this was a pretty fun spike card until I reread the activated ability and realized the target could change and other players could activate it and change the target. I'm picturing a very large burn spell with a built in redirect clause that could cause some real shenanigans.

If you had a Runed Halo out and nothing your spell could bomb on your side, it would be pretty awesome. However, the fact that you don't pitch your lands on resolution but while it's still on the stack means that you could be at severe card disadvantage if one were to counter this.

All in all this is a very red spell.

3.5/ 5

121495: Lightning Storm.author: casual_melvin
121495: Lightning Storm.text_parsed:
Cold Snap, like Time Spiral block a year later, referenced a lot of old cards and mechanics, although unlike Time Spiral, mostly from Ice Age and Alliances, the other sets in its "block".

This card references a card from the Legends expansion: Land's edge.

Skullbriar, the Walking Grave is the only other card I can think of that can have counters on it while on the stack. Epochrasite has counters on it just before being put onto the stack from exile and just after entering the battlefield but not on the stack itself.

It's a pity that proliferate doesn't interact with this. Oh well, there's always hungry hungry heifer and giant fan.

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: Mode
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed:
Yawgmoth's Will for Knights? Sounds tempting!
Buried Alive is simply amazing with him since it effectively acts as triple-creature tutor thanks to his ability - consider adding Judgement's incarnations (Filth - along with Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth, Anger, Brawn, Valor, or Wonder) or Dredge creatures like Golgari Grave-Troll (since that one allows milling a lot of cards - possibly Knights rather than drawing a card).
Intuition is a cheap tutor and can also get him into your graveyard by searching for two Haakons and a third card (e.g. Bridge from Below).
Your possible mana accel of choice is Lion's Eye Diamond, since it allows you to both discard and cast Haakon at the same time and lets you play each Knight card discarded that way.
He also synergizes greatly with Mercenary Knight since it's a cheap creature of the same tribal type which lets you discard him (or another knight which doesn't matter once he's in the graveyard). Putrid Raptor might be worth considering since it has Morph and can be turned up to the same big body by discarding a Zombie card in particular - Haakon...or other Zombie Knights like Stillmoon Cavalier.
Changelings like Cairn Wanderer, but especially instants like Nameless Inversion, Crib Swap (which might synergize with Knight of the Mists) or those from Velis Vel also do a great job since those can be used repeatedly.
Cateran Summons may find use both to grab those spells or the Mercenary Knight.
Talking about tutor cards, Survival of the Fittest will do an awesome job with Haakon to grab your most desired creatures and at the same time provide some sort of cheap card advantage, since Knights in your graveyard will be just as useful as those on your hand.
Since sacrificing Knights is also less severe, Diabolic Intent might be your choice if you do not want to include green.
Gamble also is an incredibly cheap tutor here since it's sometimes even handy if you randomly Entomb a card on your hand.
A suspended Greater Gargodon can be used to protect him (or any other knight) from getting exiled.
Locket of Yesterdays will reduce Haakon's cost automatically, and reduces your other creatures' and the changeling spells' cost as well. This will be especially handy with Court Hussar, which enables card advantage and topdecking for a single blue mana when put into the graveyard with Buried alive or Intuition. Another cost-reducing cost is Urza's Incubator (or Jet Medallion in case you're playing mainly black).
Since you can discard any knights without notable drawback try adding cards which profit from discarding cards (for example Sellshapers or some famous cards from Madness decks)
Therefore hellbent cards might find use with him as well - Infernal Tutor,
Mindstorm Crown for card advantage, Gibbering Descent (which again synergizes with Mercenary Knight), Taste for Mayhem or Rakdos Pit Dragon (which are both even more fun with Filth)
Recurring Nightmare could be used repeatedly without notable drawback by saccing a Knight to return any fatty or non-Knight (which you get in your graveyard by discarding it or by using Buried Alive)
Ashes of the Fallen will allow you to cast just any creature desired from your graveyard. (Conspiracy might be used as well in case you want them to have the same type on the battlefield as well, but when making use of Haakons ability in particular the Ashes are much cheaper.)
Cheap creatures with saccing abilities also do a great job, like Saffi Eriksdotter, Sakura-Tribe Elder or also Blood Pet to create an infinite saccing loop, or (to let this card finally have a use) Pardic Miner to prevent your opponent from playing lands.
Finally a last thing that crosses my mind is Aluren which allows recasting your creatures for free once they are destroyed and enables saccing loops - e.g. by using Court Hussar to skim through your entire library, and when you plan on using spells with storm Knight of the Mists or Mercenary Knight.

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: VoidedNote
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed: This is a good card, I have a black and white knight deck that revolves around this guy. I have several discard cards that I use on myself if I have him, some allowing me to only reveal 3 cards instead of them all, since most discards are multi or target opponent. I use the Paladins as a way to remove just about any permanant from play, then use the pentarch paladin and choose blue so i can kill anything except lands, artifacts, and white and green and enchantments for 2 mana a pop. The best part is if one dies i can just bring it back. it only fails if they get exiled really. 5/5 for his beastliness.

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: AssKickingBoots
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed:
This guy is pretty sweet, but it's easy to get similar effects from a mono white Knight deck, like with Emeria, the Sky Ruin or (although they aren't Knights) Reya Dawnbringer or Sun Titan without having to even pay their mana cost. It is worth noting this guy has a considerably cheaper cmc than Reya or the Titan though, but it's harder to cast him since you have to get him to the graveyard first.

There aren't really that many black knight cards to go with him, though Phyrexian Crusader is awesome.

This card is not worth splashing black for in your average Knight deck. Still, he can be outright evil in a deck built around him.

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: tantallum99
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed: in theory this is a great card for a knight deck, to combine with buried alive. it can lead to major card advantage because not only do you have your hand to play from, but also your graveyard. however in practice, I have found that to orchestrate everything correctly (get haakon out of your library, into your graveyard, then get him onto the battlefield so he can do his thing) it can take quite a few turns if you don't have the perfect opening hand. meaning by the time you get it rolling, you're already....dead.

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: LordRandomness
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed: Someone pointed out the somewhat unfortunate synergy that Changeling tribal instants and sorceries can be cast from your graveyard with this. Over and over and over and over. Like Nameless Inversion. Repeatable removal does not get any more efficient than 2 for +3/-3, and it's a potential power boost to boot, AND it hoses tribal, AND it sets off anything you may have that goes off on instant casting (unlikely in a black deck, but eh).

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: Salient
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed:
This is the absolute worst commander for Commander/EDH in all of Magic, and always will be. ...unless they go crazy and errata Haakon to say you can cast him from the command zone, at which point he'll be the best commander in all of Magic.

I love this card anywhere else, including in both my Knights and my pseudo-Dredge decks for Commander. He's a casual play dream card. The Nameless Inversion combo makes Merfolk decks cry; removing their Lord of Atlantis-type bonuses is almost as important as the +3/-3.

122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.author: poprockmonster
122045: Haakon, Stromgald Scourge.text_parsed: My all time favorite card. I pulled 3 when I got a Coldsnap fat pack and I knew it was fate telling me I needed a Haakon knight deck. Once he's out, Zombie Infestation lets me dump out my hand for basically free zombies, since I just then cast the discarded cards. At first graveyard hate and bounce were both super duper annoying, but then I got three Puresteel Paladins. The deck is good enough to win without ever getting Haakon going, so he's basically become my bomb, in the sense that him getting active without my friends having effective removal will usually just cause them to quit. It's been put on the "Decks I'm Not Allowed to Use" list.

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: littlebeast
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_parsed: Every time I see this card I wonder, why is that "if it's in play" clause there?
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_posted: Every time I see this card I wonder, why is that "if it's in play" clause there?

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: Ritius
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_parsed:
The "if it's in play" clause is there because if your opponent wants to save his Dark Confidant, he can just Doomblade the yeti and the damage won't be dealt, unlike the effects of Pandemonium.

If they wanted to make this guy good, they would have to take of the sorcery condition on the second ability. That and make it not cost snow.....
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_posted:
The "if it's in play" clause is there because if your opponent wants to save his [autocard]Dark Confidant[/autocard], he can just [autocard]Doomblade[/autocard] the yeti and the damage won't be dealt, unlike the effects of [autocard]Pandemonium[/autocard].

If they wanted to make this guy good, they would have to take of the sorcery condition on the second ability. That and make it not cost snow.....

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: A3Kitsune
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_parsed:
@Ritus

The bounce ability needs snow mana to be justified. Red is not a bounce color. By putting snow mana in the ability's cost, the out-of-color ability is justified by the flavor (yetis can hide in snow). And the sorcery limitation is also needed for the flavor of the ability to work.

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: majinara
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_parsed:
Not as good as FTK, but still decent. Got some of these in a red-blue snow deck of mine. Turn two coldsteel heart, turn 3 this yeti, eating up a small creature of theirs.

The bounce ability is at times of use as well. It makes him basically immune to auras like pacifism, and you can also play it prior to mass removal. Not to mention it makes opponents think twice about playing small creatures while this guy is in play.

In another deck, I also had a way of giving him persist. So he came into play, his ability triggered, I gave him persist. He dealt 3 damage to a large creature, he was killed by the creature, persisted back into play, dealt another 2 damage to that creature and got killed again.

Also good, if you have cards in play that continuously pump him, such as glorious anthem, or pump him in response to his ability, like with thriss, nantuko primus, since the yeti can then kill much larger stuff.

Also fun if you have only these yetis in play, and play travelling plague. The plague kills a creature of your opponent, your opponent has to put the plague on the yeti. In your turn you return the yeti back to your hand, allowing you to put the plague back on an opponents creature. That way you can keep killing your opponents creature with the plague (even those who have shroud, can regenerate or are indestructible), without losing anything yourself.

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: Dream_Spinner
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_parsed: @littlebeast The "if it's in play" clause is there so that when it enters the battlefield, you don't just bounce it in response to its ability triggering.  If you could, the yeti would still deal its damage to the target creature (presumably killing it) but it would be in your hand, avoiding any damage back.

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: vantha
122046: Stalking Yeti.text_parsed: The fight ability in its infant stages. I really do like that it has a 3/3 body for 4 mana. Coldsnap was a very interesting set, but it didnt have much support being a stand alone set. The best card was Adarkar Valkyrie I still think that the snow subtype was interesting but it didnt function very well outside of the block. The sorcery speed unsummon is a bit restrictive and costs too much. You are basically paying 7 mana to do this in the later game. At that point you dont even have the option of pinging the opponent for Direct damage.

122046: Stalking Yeti.author: Jannissary

They need to errata the Yeti's ability so that it just states that it fights a creature.

Also; it's somewhat flavorful, but I just can't get into this guy. He fights a guy and unsummons himself- but it's so expensive! I don't see how a repeatable fighting Yeti for 2RR and a snow mana would be so bad. You're already paying out the nose for a lightning bolt with a body.

122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.author: KnightLord77
122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.text_parsed:
What a great card! There are so many good combinations that can be used with it! Soul Warden, Field Marshal, Angelic Chorus, Mobilization, and the list goes on!

It's too bad that they haven't reprinted this card, although I wouldn't want them to change the artwork or anything. (On second thought, maybe it's better that they haven't reprinted it!) But, as a side note, I like it better with the creature type saying "Human Lord," rather than "Human Soldier." Sure, sure, it makes it a better card to have it say "Human Soldier," but it fits better to have a Legendary King creature character be a "Lord." That's the whole point of a Lord character. After all, he's not just another soldier, any more that Lord of the Undead is just another zombie.
122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.text_posted:

It's too bad that they haven't reprinted this card, although I wouldn't want them to change the artwork or anything. (On second thought, maybe it's better that they [i]haven't[/i] reprinted it!) But, as a side note, I like it better with the creature type saying "Human Lord," rather than "Human Soldier." 122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.author: RJDroid
122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.text_parsed:
He's pretty awesome in my Ghave, Guru of Spores deck.
Oh, you hit me for 10? Ok, I'll just sacrifice all those tokens and put them on Ghave and swing back for lethal. Or sacrifice them to Vish Kal for precision removal. Or have Mentor of the Meek out, which basically says "Whenever you are dealt damage, you may pay X, where X is between 0 and the amount of damage dealt to you. If you do, draw X cards."

Or, if you're in a tight spot, you can use them as chump blockers next turn.

Of course, in practice, most people try to kill him on sight before the craziness gets going, but that just means that your dozens of other bombs stick around to mess things up. The 3/3 body can hurt with big damage sweepers in the format.

All in all, 4/5.

122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.author: konokono
122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.text_parsed: I'm not normally one who rates down a creature because it "dies to removal", because a lot of cards, i.e. Baneslayer, is an immediate threat on the next turn if the opponent doesn't have removal in hand. The problem with this card is that unless you have some way to damage yourself, your opponent gets to choose whether it's worth damaging you or not, and if it's not, he can just sit and wait for a removal, while Darien isn't affecting the board position much. 4/5

122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.author: WolfWhoWalks
122049: Darien, King of Kjeldor.text_parsed: I used to use Darien exclusively as the commander for my white weenie soldier tribal deck. Then I discovered Odric, Master Tactician, whom, after lengthy trials, I now prefer. Darien's good defense, but there are times when taking a hit to generate tokens isn't worth it (for example, fatty commanders dealing commander damage). I now vastly prefer taking the weenie aggro to the opponent with Odric, and his nifty "you choose not to block anything" ability.

122052: Surging Aether.author: jeff-heikkinen
122052: Surging Aether.text_parsed:
I just can't bring myself to like anything that asks me to pay more than 3 mana to bounce a single permanent (if it uses up a card - reusable abilities are another matter entirely). You just won't gain enough tempo for it to be worth the card, usually. That this will bounce a second thing once in a blue moon helps, but realistically, how often does Ripple work? I might sideboard this in in Limited if I knew my opponent used Auras and/or things with comes-into-play drawbacks a lot, but even then it's by no means a no-brainer.

I suppose if you drafted a critical mass of these they'd end up being pretty good, but going into a draft with the intention of doing so isn't a plan, it's a hail Mary pass.

(The censor is ridiculous, by the way.)

So I'm just double checking to see if i fully understand how this card works.

"At the beginning of each end step, each player gains control of all nontoken permanents he or she owns."

Owns = the cards you bring to the table before the games start.
Controls = the cards on your side of the field.

So at the end of turn, if anyone has control of your land (annex) you reagian control of your land?

 "At the beginning of each end step, each player gains [b]control[/b] of all nontoken permanents he or she [b]owns[/b]."

Owns = the cards you bring to the table before the games start.
Controls = the cards on your side of the field.

So at the end of turn, if anyone has control of your land (annex) you reagian control of your land?

122055: Brooding Saurian.author: KarmasPayment
122055: Brooding Saurian.text_parsed:
Yes, Owns is anything that was originally in your deck (or sideboard in some cases) excluding tokens put into play by a spell or ability of yours under the control of an opponent. Such as Forbidden Orchard, tokens made by you in those ways and put under an opponents control are now also owned by that opponent instead of you.
(Even though the saurian doesn't effect tokens anyways)

But yes, you would re-gain control of stolen non-token permanents you own (treachery'd/Vedalken Shackles'd/memnarch'd or otherwise) at the end of each turn.

122056: Balduvian Warlord.author: DoctorKenneth
122056: Balduvian Warlord.text_parsed:
Here, let me help you out with that.

*Tap*

Okay, see how you just blocked my 8/8 with your 1/1? That 1/1 is now blocking THIS 2/2 guy instead. Now, are there any more guys blocking my 8/8? No? Then I guess it's not blocked.

Or, if you wanted, you could switch one of your own blockers to another creature. For some reason. Maybe if your opponent is being a jerk and saying "No, no, you took your hand off the card, that block is final."


A tricky way of red getting something through. Not always a useful trick, especially if you've only got a single useful attacker. But it's not too bad.

122056: Balduvian Warlord.author: longwinded
122056: Balduvian Warlord.text_parsed:
"Wait a minute. Somethings wrong here. You see this text?"
"Yeah, I see it.... We don't use the word 'blocked' much anymore. We better change those two instances to 'was blocking'."
"Good call. That could have just been confusing."

But seriously, the goal is that you can veto one of the defending player's blocking assignments. That creature still blocks something else (your call) and if whatever it was originally blocking is the only valid choice, you have to let it go right back to blocking that guy. But 90% of the time, you get to say, "No, I think your 1/1 would be better off not blocking my 8/8. Here, he can block my 2/2 instead. Oh look, you're both dead."

edit: I also love how I managed to type out almost exactly the same example before I read DoctorKenneth's comment.

122056: Balduvian Warlord.author: casual_melvin
122056: Balduvian Warlord.text_parsed:
Sooooo many tricks with this card.

The obvious is to get your giant creature past a chump blocker, and if the opponent double chumps they're down an extra creature.

There are also cards that trigger on blocking or being blocked, or cards like smite that have targeting conditions.

Looking at the rulings shows another trick. Two of these can block three creatures. Have both block the same creature, then switch each to a different creature and the original remains blocked.



I also quite enjoy the wall of text. Seven lines of text, on an uncommon, really makes this card fit right in with the ice age cards cold snap was emulating.

and 4 mana for a 3/2 isn't entirely unplayable either. 3.5/5

122057: Deepfire Elemental.text_parsed: I agree with themicronaut here, it sounds totally awesome.. creature destruction and artifact destruction for a 6 mana creature, cool.  Then I look again, and I realize the xx means pay the casting cost twice of whatever your trying to destroy.. ehh.. not so good.  If it only costs 3 for my opponent it costs me 7 mana to destroy it.. even a 2 mana artifact now costs 5 to take off the field.  It would be awesome if you could use it to take their big creatures off the field.. but you would have to pay its casting cost twice which if its the usual 6 or so.. is 13 with the 1 colorless.  You're never going to play 13 mana to remove one creature, instead of just doom blading it, or what have you.  A cruel ultimatum only costs 7 by comparison.  Also not counting that what if your target creature has regeneration, or they save it at the last minute with a protection card, you spent all your mana to make your opponent use up one spell or a couple mana worth of regeneration, ouch.

122066: Jester's Scepter.author: Fictionarious
122066: Jester's Scepter.text_parsed:
It doesn't say they go back on the Library if it leaves play... hmm.
Looks like a wonderful new toy for a Vedalken Mastermind.

Also, a question from one budding expert to another:

I cast the Scepter and morphxile five cards from my opponent's library.
When I return the scepter to my hand with Vedalken Mastermind, it leaves play.
Then when it I recast it next turn, it enters the battlefield as a whole new permanent with no relation to it's previous existance. Since when a card refers to itself by name, it refers to the specific permanent it is and not any other permanents that share it's name or permanents that did at one time share it's name, it DOESN'T allow me to use the first five cards I morphxiled as counter fodder, only the newer set of five.
Right? Or wrong?

122069: Sheltering Ancient.author: cats_and_me
122069: Sheltering Ancient.text_parsed:
Good ideas here, but there are still other cards that punish creatures for having counters on them: Razorfin Abolisher, Hunter Of Eyeblights, Cytoplast Manipulator, Kulrath Knight.. However, notice the anti-synergy between removing creatures from the other side of the board and the cumulative upkeep cost! :(

Another idea would be punishing enemy creatures for having a high power or toughness with cards like Crackdown, Meekstone, Intrepid Hero.. Maybe it's just my personal opinion, but I don't understand why many cards that depend on your opponent having creatures have such a high rating? Yeah, there's Forbidden Orchard and some other cards, but you have to draw it first.. If you're going first, casting this on the second turn without having to sacrifice it can be hard! :(

122071: Vexing Sphinx.author: majinara
122071: Vexing Sphinx.text_parsed:
This guy is actually very nice. I'm using it in a blue-black reanimation deck. Ideally it's turn two lightning greaves, turn three this, equip and swing for 4, turn 4 discard something large, zombify, equip with greaves and swing for 10 or more. Not tournament worthy but solid.

If you just play it, attack for two turns and then let it die, you basically had a 4/4 blocker on turn three, dealt 8 damage, discarded your three worst cards and drew three new ones. That's far from bad.

Now if your deck has a graveyard theme it becomes even better. Discarding cards with madness, flashback, unearth, retrace, incarnations, stuff to reanimate or aquiring threshold in general. Also helps you out if you are mana-flooded, allowing you to discard excess lands and draw other stuff instead.

4/5 ****
122071: Vexing Sphinx.text_posted:
This guy is actually very nice. I'm using it in a blue-black reanimation deck. Ideally it's turn two lightning greaves, turn three this, equip and swing for 4, turn 4 discard something large, zombify, equip with greaves and swing for 10 or more. Not tournament worthy but solid.

If you just play it, attack for two turns and then let it die, you basically had a 4/4 blocker on turn three, dealt 8 damage, discarded your three worst cards and drew three new ones. That's far from bad.

Now if your deck has a graveyard theme it becomes even better. Discarding cards with madness, flashback, unearth, retrace, incarnations, stuff to reanimate or aquiring threshold in general. Also helps you out if you are mana-flooded, allowing you to discard excess lands and draw other stuff instead.

4/5 ****

122071: Vexing Sphinx.author: Technetium
122071: Vexing Sphinx.text_parsed: I find this card to work pretty effectively. It's a cheap medium-fatty that doesn't find some way to tie your mana down subsequent turns (like echo or cumulative upkeep). The penalty easily turns into a card advantage bonus if you only use it for a single attack and then let it die for 2 cards. I like to use it with cards like Daze and Gush so I have Islands in my hand to discard. Blue doesn't need a lot of lands in play to work.

122073: Shape of the Wiitigo.author: majinara
122073: Shape of the Wiitigo.text_parsed:
The good:
- I like the art
- very flavorful
- even if the aura gets destroyed, the counters remain on the creature
- great with doubling season
- great with any creature using +1/+1 counters (triskelion or ulasht, the hate seed for example)
- unlike equipment, can be also played on the creatures of teammates, in team based games

The bad:
- if the creature gets destroyed or stolen or bounced or anything, you lose two cards at once (typical aura problem)
- manacost is too high

Or in other words: no tournament quality, but a nice casual card to reload your trike or whatever.

122075: Jötun Grunt.author: achilleselbow
122075: Jötun Grunt.text_parsed: It's not a misprint. The point is that if you played it on turn two, you would likely not be able to pay its upkeep even once, and by late game it might be better to have a more expensive 4/4 that sticks around rather than one who will die in a few turns unless you have some way to constantly feed your graveyard. That's the logic, anyway. Of course, this card has many fun uses. I'd love to see more cards like this rather than stuff like Leatherback Baloth.

Played an EDH game tonight against a guy who had this and Fleshbag Marauder at the same time. It was brutal.

Cast Harvest, get a dude back. Cast Marauder, sac him to his own trigger and make everyone else sac a dude, Recover Harvest. Next turn Harvest for the Marauder, cast Marauder again, Recover the Harvest...rinse and repeat ad nauseam. Nasty.

122114: Grim Harvest.author: Lash_of_Dragonbreath
122114: Grim Harvest.text_parsed:
@Blobman: no, the thing actually is that this card is reusable. So, while Disentomb may be 1 cheaper, this offers you card advantage. Also, in a dredge deck you could fish this out of your graveyard if you end dredging it by accident. And it's an Instant, so you can spend your spare mana on it at the end of an opponent's turn.
Not saying it's the best card ever, but it's still a nifty little trick to pull in casual or multiplayer.

On a side note, am I the only one who notices how well Void Maw works with recover?

122116: Rimefeather Owl.author: OmegaSerris
122116: Rimefeather Owl.text_parsed:
It's not "you control", it's "in play". Think of limited, how big this thing would be. Think of mirror matches (For a more recent example, Strata Scythe). It's not bad on it's own, but to be great, it needs some support. Rimescale Dragon is a very good example, throws ice counters AND makes the counters thrown with this guy even better. Then there are other things in block that can only interact with snow permanents. You can also use the him to enable a party of snow-landwalk or even an Avalanche. Just search "snow land" in the text to see how many toys this guy can power.

I agree though, useless outside of block or in a deck without any support. But that's like putting Elvish Champion in a Beast tribal deck, dumb.

122118: Surging Sentinels.author: djflo
122118: Surging Sentinels.text_parsed: Ripple cards were basically designed for limited because most stores weren't stocked with Ice Age or Fallen Empires boosters (or they were prohibitively expensive to use for sealed). This resulted in most Coldsnap sealed formats being Coldsnap alone, so the variance of cards was much lower than normal. Ripple was thus quite potent in that format (but the constructed applications were extremely limited).

122122: Mishra's Bauble.author: YotianSoldier
122122: Mishra's Bauble.text_parsed:
This, and Urza's Bauble rock. I often make stream-lined decks under 60 cards, and adding these makes them legal, (at a slight cost of deck speed). My 52 card transmogrant deck uses these to fill it out, and has Salavging Station as part of the combo. So Salvaging the baubles gives it a little more card draw for free. I have about 6 sets of the baubles in use in my decks.
I would agree that Mishra's is slightly better than Urza's

122123: Braid of Fire.author: Vinifera7
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed: Without mana burn as of M2010's rule changes, this card becomes MUCH more powerful. There's virtually no incentive NOT to get the mana dumped on you each upkeep. 122123: Braid of Fire.author: Mode
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
Since M10, this is indeed a nice card.
Either spend the mana for instants in burn decks, activated abilities, or pay upkeep costs, including those from cultimative upkeep cost since they can equate each other,
for example Brand of Ill Omen, Earthen Goo, Halls of Mist, Heat Wave and Magmatic Core.
Further cultimative upkeep cards of other colors that can make use of this include: Hibernation's End, Wave of Terror, Musician, Corrosion, Elephant Grass, Energy Storm, Fyndhorn Pollen, Kjeldoran Javelineer, Malignant Growth, Mesmeric Trance, Mystic Remora, Prismatic Circle and Revered Unicorn.

122123: Braid of Fire.author: SleetFox
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
In any other color this card would be unbelievable. It's still absolutely fantastic, but red often won't see the game go long enough to have this get insane. That's not to say that you can't make a somewhat slower red deck, but for the really fast ones you'd most likely be better off with Desperate Ritual or Seething Song.

Now that Worldwake is out and Rise of the Eldrazi is coming, Comet Storm and the Eldrazi are now awesome with this card. Since it's supposed to have a lot of slowing cards, this should be able to really shine.

122123: Braid of Fire.author: keeds4
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
Obviously, with mana burn eliminated from the rules in 2010, the upkeep is now an immense advantage. This is another example of how current rule changes or card released can suddenly elevate cards released in the past. Remember when Lion's Eye Diamond was lame because of its costly drawback? Then, Yawgmoth's Will came along and the diamond became THE artifact to have.

Actually, I thought that mana burn was a good rule -- it added that sense of constraint and challenge to the game. Now, people can just tap out and absent-mindedly let mana drain from their pools without any consequence. I dunno -- cards like Drain Power were fun with mana burn as a rule.
122123: Braid of Fire.text_posted:

Now, people can just tap out and absent-mindedly let mana drain from their pools without any consequence. I dunno -- cards like [autocard]Drain Power[/autocard] were fun with mana burn as a rule.

122123: Braid of Fire.author: MTGfan9000
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed: This card makes no sense to me unless it is used to finish off your opponent with spells that can be cast during the upkeep step that would benefit from having a lot more mana than you would without it. Because otherwise you just lose it all to pay it's upkeep cost. Get X red mana but have to pay that X red mana in upkeep. Using the mana for anything that doesn't end the game in that step is pointless because you would then have to pay that amount of mana used from other normal mana sources for the upkeep cost and defeating the purpose of getting the mana from the card. Unless of course you don't use the mana at all for an extended period of time to use it as a time bomb so to speak and not pay it's upkeep. Of course the longer it is in play the more likely your opponent will be able to get rid of it.

122123: Braid of Fire.author: Mid_Squad
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
I noticed someone else posted something pretty much exactly the same as this. I'm not stealing your ideas, haha. Just think of it as great minds thinking alike.

One of my favorite decks uses this card and Soulbright Flamekin. Why?

Turn 1: Mountain, Flamekin Harbinger (Find either Soulbright Flamekin or something like Magmatic Force if you already have Soulbright.
Turn 2: Mountain, this card.
Turn 3: Mountain, Soulbright Flamekin (1 red mana)
Turn 4: Mountain, activate Soulbright's ability once during upkeep, twice during your turn, and you have 8 mana to do whatever you want. Either drop the Magmatic Force you found, or drop one of my favorite cards, Avatar of Slaughter.

There are 19 different cards you would be able to play on turn 4. Here are probably the best ones: Akroma, Angel of Fury, Din of the Fireherd (3 out of 4 lands gone if they werent ramping), Magmatic Force, Avatar of Slaughter, Scourge of Kher Ridges... There's probably other good cards such as artifacts and 7 cost and lower creatures that I didnt check. And you thought mana ramping was a green thing...

122123: Braid of Fire.author: LastProtagonist
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
Not as good as it used to be due to a change in ruling on how mana exists between steps and phases:
http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/feature/42a

Basically, you mana pool empties between your upkeep step and draw step...meaning you can only play instants with mana from Braid of Fire.
122123: Braid of Fire.text_posted:
Not as good as it used to be due to a change in ruling on how mana exists between steps and phases:

122123: Braid of Fire.author: applecorn
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
During your upkeep this triggers. At the end of your upkeep >POOF< it's gone. So yes instants and abilities come to mind. But, perhaps there's more? What if could use that Free Mana to pay cumulative upkeep costs?! Opens whole new doors.

This has previously been explored via Mode:
Since M10, this is indeed a nice card.
Either spend the mana for instants in burn decks, activated abilities, or pay upkeep costs, including those from cultimative upkeep cost since they can equate each other,
for example Brand of Ill Omen, Earthen Goo, Halls of Mist, Heat Wave and Magmatic Core.
Further cultimative upkeep cards of other colors that can make use of this include: Hibernation's End, Wave of Terror, Musician, Corrosion, Elephant Grass, Energy Storm, Fyndhorn Pollen, Kjeldoran Javelineer, Malignant Growth, Mesmeric Trance, Mystic Remora, Prismatic Circle and Revered Unicorn.

To expand on that, only red mana or colorless was addressed. Change the color you're given. Black: Agent of Stromgald or Bog Initiate. White: Skyshroud Elf. For each 2 mana spent, we could get any color with Gemstone Array. There are other options, but would require either A) to tap the artifact/creature/land to filter; B) Sacrifice said perm; or C) Limited to X times per turn. Not a win/win for this ability. I don't want to expand on Gemstone Array because would be losing half the upkeep each turn. So, now that shown we get free upkeep colored mana, let's look at options. Black: Infernal Darkness, Krovikan Whispers, Phobian Phantasm, Phyrexian Etchings. White: Arctic Nishoba, Jötun Owl Keeper, Royal Decree. Must I list all the new abilities and instances now for these new colors?! Too bad; those you can find, I'm sure.

122123: Braid of Fire.author: HorseofaThousandEyes
122123: Braid of Fire.text_parsed:
LastProtagonist:
Not as good as it used to be due to a change in ruling on how mana exists between steps and phases:
http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/feature/42a

Basically, you mana pool empties between your upkeep step and draw step...meaning you can only play instants with mana from Braid of Fire.

Actually, it pretty much does work the same way.Your mana pool already emptied between upkeep and main phase, except it was only done after your draw step, and now does so at the end of upkeep as well (so technically empties twice).

Wizards were a bit ambiguous with how they referred to cards that were to be errataed and not - the two that are noted to be errataed refer to mana not emptying from pools at ends of phases, and had to be updated to include at end of steps as well. Braid wasn't because the rules change only means that the mana can't be used during your draw step, which is not really going to matter much.

Sadly too slow, and too awkward to utilize fully, except possibly in EDH. Shame is isn't in black :-/

122124: Arcum Dagsson.author: sonorhC
122124: Arcum Dagsson.text_parsed: Nucleon, you don't know the half of it. I've put together an Arcum EDH deck that can literally play every card in the deck by turn 7 or quicker (turn 6 in the goldfish match, but against real opponents you probably want to spend a turn fetching up some protection for him, like a Swiftfoot Boots). The key combo is Arcum, Thornbite Staff, Summoning Station, and Mycosynth Lattice (all of which can be fetched up by Arcum, of course). Tap the Summoning Station to make a Pincher, and it's an artifact due to Mycosynth, so eligible for sacrifice. Tap Arcum and sacrifice the Pincher to fetch up whatever you want, and the Pincher dying triggers the abilities on the Summoning Station and the Staff, untapping both the Station and Arcum. Lather, rinse, repeat.

122124: Arcum Dagsson.author: JinChonRei
122124: Arcum Dagsson.text_parsed:
In my opinion one of the very best Generals in EDH, his versatility and his uncanny ability make him a force to be reckoned with. while other commanders rely on alot of removal tactics, combat and additional tutoring for good cards to make things happen, i am looking at hegdgemon and glissa, this guy here gets fed one tiny stupid myr and he can turn the whole game around in a few turns. pull out those lightning greaves and the darksteel forge, turn him into and artifact, give your indestructible hexproof general wings andn copy him with mirrorworks combined with mirror gallery and watch the world burn...

you could also use karn the silver golem to put lightning greaves on your newly created artifact creature named darksteel forge. can shove that improved avacyn into your newly fetched conjurer's closet. all fetched by tinker on legs...

if you are worried about finding your creatures, well you can always mill yourself with cards like keening stone and then fetch karn the liberated with stuff like Argivian Restoration, drafna's restoration etc. and then just elixir of immortality the rest back in your library. the only thing you need to worry about is red damage spells and blue of course...the rest is in complete lockdown.

124451: Thrumming Stone.author: majinara
124451: Thrumming Stone.text_parsed:
The best way to use is with Beacons. Like Beacon of Unrest (which could also return the Thrumming stone back to play in case it gets destroyed) or Beacon of Destruction. Then you should thin your library as quickly as possible. The fewer cards there left, the higher the chance the beacons will turn up.

I got a blue-black deck around that, using hand disruption and bounce to buy time, and many small cantrips and card drawers to thin the library. Since they ripple as well, this works very quickly. No tournament deck, but still fun.

124451: Thrumming Stone.author: pbangarth
124451: Thrumming Stone.text_parsed:
Have a look at this card in conjunction with Relentless Rats (2/2), the ones which can have more than four copies in the deck. As soon as this card comes out, the next casting of a Relentless Rat basically empties the deck of all the rats and puts them into play, each one giving all the others +1/+1. With 20 of the rats in the deck, you soon have 20 X 21/21 Rats in play.

I thought I had a decent deck, until I faced this travesty.
